item.title: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

If it’s less than 20 questions I’d use a PHP array, if more than 20 I’d use a simple two columned table in a database, would make managing it a lot easier, and updating/editing would be easier than your text file approach.

Read full topic

item.source: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)

item.title: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

Saige:

It’s just I want it to be in a notepad so I can add a sentence in then im done, and I can number them off as well. Would you have any idea how to do this?

I’m sure you could, but it would literally be 10x harder, because browsers sandbox scripts so they can’t access local files. So you couldn’t cache them into the users filesystem. And if you saved it on the server, then you’d have to do way more programming just to be able to access the file, when you could have just added a comma and some quotation marks inside of an array.

Read full topic

item.title: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Saige, post:41, topic:525682”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=644422.msg4336621#msg4336621 date=1374478690]

No you need to add an html element with an id, so you can manipulate it with js.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Title</title>
</head>
<body>
  <p id="update_paragraph"></p>
  <script src="my_script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

Also, sorry, forgot to times the minutes by 10 in the script

var counter = 0;

function update() {
        document.getElementById('update_paragraph').innerHTML = lines[counter];
        counter++;
        setTimeout(update, 1000 * 60 * 10);
}

update();

So this code will change echo $lines[0]; from “0” to “1” after 10 minutes?

Yeah, but make sure to actually have an array named “lines” or it will just display nothing(or undefined, not sure).

var lines = ['Drugs are bad, mmk.', 'Whateva, whateva, I do wat I want', 'Would you like to suck my balls, Mr Garrison?'];

Also, theres no reason for “echo” anything. This is client sided, meaning its code that is run on the users browser. Theres no need to use a server sided language to try and manipulate client elements
[/quote]

Will this code above that you wrote make the “0” in this code change?

[code=php]<?php
$myFile = “Question.txt”;
$lines = file($myFile);
echo $lines[0];
?>

[/code][/quote]

You seem to have a core misunderstanding of the difference between client and server code. As far as I know(think somebody in this post said otherwise), php only produces static pages. Meaning you’d have to refresh the page to see any changes after the page has already been displayed. On top of that, I think that you’d have to use cookies or something to even store that data. javascript can do all of that in real time, without having to refresh the page, because its being run client sided(in your browser), and not server sided(on the web host)

Read full topic
item.source: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)

item.title: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)
item.dc:creator: @Saige Saige
item.description:
@Saige wrote:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:20, topic:525682”][quote author=Saige link=topic=644422.msg4336611#msg4336611 date=1374477284]

No you need to add an html element with an id, so you can manipulate it with js.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Title</title>
</head>
<body>
  <p id="update_paragraph"></p>
  <script src="my_script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

Also, sorry, forgot to times the minutes by 10 in the script

var counter = 0;

function update() {
        document.getElementById('update_paragraph').innerHTML = lines[counter];
        counter++;
        setTimeout(update, 1000 * 60 * 10);
}

update();

So this code will change echo $lines[0]; from “0” to “1” after 10 minutes?
[/quote]

Yeah, but make sure to actually have an array named “lines” or it will just display nothing(or undefined, not sure).

var lines = ['Drugs are bad, mmk.', 'Whateva, whateva, I do wat I want', 'Would you like to suck my balls, Mr Garrison?'];

Also, theres no reason for “echo” anything. This is client sided, meaning its code that is run on the users browser. Theres no need to use a server sided language to try and manipulate client elements[/quote]

Will this code above that you wrote make the “0” in this code change?

[code=php]<?php
$myFile = “Question.txt”;
$lines = file($myFile);
echo $lines[0];
?>

[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Timer on PHP code (Still need help)
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Saige, post:30, topic:525682”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=644422.msg4337069#msg4337069 date=1374541750]

It’s kind of going to be a quiz and I just want it to rotate through different questions that I have put into a .txt file.

Why not make it random?

$questions = array("Question 1", "Question 2", "Question 3");

$index = mt_rand(0,2);

echo $questions[$index];

Just post it to a script with the index in it as a hidden input and match it to an answer.
[/quote]

I know how to do it random I was just wanted it to change questions every ten minutes.[/quote]
Then do as I said earlier, run a cron job to update the integer every 10 minutes.

Read full topic
